eeguana 0.1.1.9000

Dplyr verbs overloaded for manipulating eeg_lst objects.

Source: R/dplyr_verbs.R
dplyr_verbs.Rd

Manipulate the signal table and the segments table of an eeg_lst.

# S3 method for eeg_lst
mutate(.data, ...)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
transmute(.data, ...)

filter.eeg_lst(.data, ..., .preserve = FALSE)

filter.eeg_ica_lst(.data, ..., .preserve = FALSE)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
summarise(.data, ...)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
group_by(.data, ..., add = FALSE, .drop = FALSE)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
ungroup(.data, ...)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
select(.data, ...)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
rename(.data, ...)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
groups(x)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
group_vars(x)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
anti_join(x, y, by = NULL, copy = FALSE,
  suffix = c(".x", ".y"), ...)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
left_join(x, y, by = NULL, copy = FALSE,
  suffix = c(".x", ".y"), ...)

# S3 method for eeg_lst
semi_join(x, y, by = NULL, suffix = c(".x", ".y"),
  ...)

tbl_vars.eeg_lst(x)

Arguments

.data

An eeg_lst.
...

Name-value pairs of expressions; see dplyr for more help.
.preserve

Not in use, for compatibility reasons.
add

Not in use, for compatibility reasons.
.drop

When .drop = TRUE, empty groups are dropped. (FALSE by default.)
x

An eeg_lst.
y

A data frame, tibble, or data.table.
by

a character vector of variables to join by. If NULL, the default, *_join() will do a natural join, using all variables with common names across the two tables. A message lists the variables so that you can check they're right (to suppress the message, simply explicitly list the variables that you want to join).

To join by different variables on x and y use a named vector. For example, by = c("a" = "b") will match x.a to y.b.
copy

If x and y are not from the same data source, and copy is TRUE, then y will be copied into the same src as x. This allows you to join tables across srcs, but it is a potentially expensive operation so you must opt into it.
suffix

If there are non-joined duplicate variables in x and y, these suffixes will be added to the output to disambiguate them. Should be a character vector of length 2.

Value

An eeg_lst object.

Details

Wrappers for dplyr's commands that act on different parts eeg_lst objects. Functions that drop or rename column won't remove columns starting with a dot. The following wrappers act in a special way for eeg_lst objects:

  • *_join(): joins an external table to the segments table of the eeg_lst.

  • mutate() and transmute() Variables that are a function of a channel are added to the signal_tbl table, and other variables are added to the segments table.

  • summarize() summarizes the channel of the signal_tbl table.

In addition, _at(), and _if() versions of the functions should work as well. Notice that the _at() versions are much faster than the _if() versions of these commands.

See also

Other dplyr functions: bind, slice_signal

Examples

library(dplyr)
# Create new channel in the signal table
data_faces_ERPs %>%
  mutate(tmp = Fz - Cz)
#> # EEG data:
#> # Grouped by: .sample, 
#> # Grouped by: condition, 
#> # Grouped by: .recording,

# Create a new condition in the segments table
data_faces_ERPs %>%
  mutate(code = ifelse(condition == "faces", 1, -1))

# Create a new channel and drop all others
data_faces_ERPs %>%
  transmute(Occipital = chs_mean(O1, O2, Oz,
    na.rm = TRUE
  ))
#> # EEG data:
#> # Grouped by: .sample, 
#> # Grouped by: condition, 
#> # Grouped by: .recording, 
#> 
#> # Signal table:
#>      .id .sample Occipital
#>   1:   1     -99 0.7805137
#>   2:   1     -98 0.8608763
#>   3:   1     -97 1.0441154
#>   4:   1     -96 1.1646338
#>   5:   1     -95 1.2251724
#>  ---                      
#> 448:   2     122 9.4315997

# Extract data associated with a condition
data_faces_ERPs %>%
  filter(condition == "faces")

# Group and summarize
data_faces_ERPs %>%
  # Convert samples to times, filter between timepoints
  filter(between(
    as_time(.sample, unit = "ms"),
    100, 200
  )) %>%
  # Find mean amplitude of Fz for each condition
  group_by(condition) %>%
  summarize(mean.amplitude = mean(Fz))
#> # EEG data:
#> # Grouped by: condition, 
#> 
#> # Signal table:
#>    .id .sample mean.amplitude
#> 1:   1      NA      -1.123384
#> 2:   2      NA      -5.701296
#> 
#> # Events table:
#> No events.
#> 
#> # Segments table:
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#> # Groups:   condition [2]
#>     .id condition .recording
#>   <int> <chr>     <chr>     
#> 1     1 faces     faces.vhdr
#> 2     2 non-faces faces.vhdr

# Select specific electrodes
data_faces_ERPs %>%
  select(O1, O2, P7, P8)
#> Adding missing grouping variables: .sample

data_faces_ERPs %>%
  rename(Predictor = condition)
